Goal 3: Good Health and Well-being
Target 3.8: Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
Indicator 3.8.1: Coverage with essential health services (excluding reproductive, maternal, newborn and adolescent health) as a percentage of the population (global estimate)
Indicator 3.8.2: Proportion of the population with large household expenditures on health as a share of total household income for private households (National/Subnational level)
Indicator 3.8.3: Average time taken by the population to get to a health facility from the place of residence, in minutes (global estimate)
Indicator 3.8.4: Proportion of the population who suffer catastrophic health expenditures (THat is, those facing financial difficulties following payment for health services and whose total health expenses exceed a specified fraction of their income or a specified percentage of the national poverty line) (National/Subnational level)
Indicator 3.8.5: Proportion of population in need of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) antiretroviral therapy who receive sustained antiretroviral therapy (National/Subnational level)
Indicator 3.8.6: Proportion of Tuberculosis-infected individuals that were tested and notified (global estimate)
Indicator 3.8.7: Proportion of the population aged 15 years and over screened for raised blood pressure (National/Subnational level)
Indicator 3.8.a: Coverage with information and services, as well as access to education and communication to help prevent, identify and respond early to deviations from normal growth and development in children under five (National/Subnational level)

13. 气候行动 (Climate Action)

The text discusses the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and its actions to mitigate and adapt to climate change, particularly in the water and energy sectors as mentioned in the "2017-2020 National Strategy for Managing Agricultural Risks and Developing Climate Resilient Agriculture" (Paragraph 3). However, the UNFCCC expresses concern that the signatory countries are not following the path to fulfill their national self-contribution commitments in forestry and agriculture sectors (Paragraph 2). Similarly, the UNFCCC is worried about the increasing emissions of greenhouse gases and the lack of capacity for signatory countries to compile a national greenhouse gas inventory (Paragraph 2). The UNFCCC also noticed that there is a lack of coordination and cooperation between departments responsible for updating, implementing, and monitoring national self-contribution commitments (Paragraph 4). These issues align most closely with the Climate Action category.
